data.text: Cheapest Gps Unit for Bike Tour Navigation?

Hi all. I'm looking to find the cheapest (or at least cheap!) gps unit that can be used for navigation. I can't get google to understand that I'm only interested in navigation and don't care about speed, cadence, logging my route etc Ideally, I wan't something where I can plan on my mobile and upload to the unit using osmand+ and not be forced to use closed source apps on my phone... this bit may be more difficult to achieve! Quick edit: I'm using my phone for the job at the moment but battery life is terrible using navigation and the gps signal keeps getting lost so please no more "Use your phone" suggestions!
Why not just use your phone for the navigation ?
data.author: Alan Tucker

data.text: battery life becomes awful and it keeps losing the gps signal
data.author: James Fenn

data.text: have you turned of WiFi, bluetooth etc , my phone easily lasts all day navigating , including playing music and a few photographs
data.author: Alan Tucker

data.text: yes I have. I don't know why mine is so pathetic for on-bike navigation. I use it as a car satnav: plugged in and with the screen on, using google maps and it's fine. With the screen off and not connected to a power source, using any other navigation software, it doesn't fare too well. Tech rant: I figure that the android library code for agps drops the 'assisted' part when I use navigation software with the screen off as a power saving feature. This is something I have no options available in my settings for changing... The conspiracy theorist inside of me thinks that google inc. (alphabet) is aware of this issue but is unlikely to fix it as it suits them fine. I don't particularly care for Alphabet inc., a massive advertising company, knowing my location 24hrs a day without my consent - a capability that is on the level of GCHQ or other spook's access to information. So I want a standalone gps and will put LineageOS with microg on my phone! Tech rant over!

data.text: I just purchased a used Edge 810 and still have my Edge Touring both are great. Paid 150CAD. It came with US and CAN and I downloaded Europe maps for 31.00 CAD. These are the two best units because they have an external storage micro SD card slot for up to 32GB. Works for me.
data.author: Lou Roussinos

data.text: Furthermore battery life is 11 hours for the 810 and with a new battery for 35 bucks I can get 17 hours. Don't need it. The explorer gets 8 hours of life.

data.text: You probably already have one! A smartphone. Traveled 1220 miles last summer, using Google maps.

data.text: I use a Lezyne GPS because at ¬£135 its cheaper than Garmin and works brilliantly, with a battery life over 12 hours in full navigation. You still need to use the Lezyne app, but you can load routes directly to the unit via a PC if you prefer. Or use routes that are saved on Komoot.

data.text: Speed and logging are such trivial and popular features that you'll probably not find something without. Cadence requires an add-on sensor, so if you don't buy that you're not paying a penalty. The actual cost is things like display, and navigation algorithms...

data.text: Do you have it out in the line of sight of the satellites? Does it take time to get a fix on the gps signal? Does it work in cities?
data.author: James Fenn

data.text: takes good 20 minutes to fix from cold start but once it fixes its all good... depends if in the city with high buildings or its super cloudy or not ... probably so long because no cellular connection just plain GPS... Yeah it does work in the cities. I once done a 20 mile walk from central Osaka, Japan to the suburbs... had s small battery bank to charge up and plenty of spare time. I get bit confused there once, it wanted me to get over other side of river but there was only train bridge on sight, i had a closer look and there was also pederastian underpass available...xcover2 is rugged and waterproof happy to sit on handlebars.

data.text: Mapsme. You download the region/city where you want to bike, and then you should put it on airplane mode while you bike so it uses very little battery. Occasionally you might have to get it off airplane mode to recalibrate where you are and then put it back on, but normally even on airplane mode it tells you where you are.

data.text: There is no cheap was to get mapping on your bike computer. Maps tend to be a feature on higher-end units, only, as an add-on to all the base features you say you don't care about. That's the reality. My recommendation is to bite the bullet and get a good bike computer.

data.text: Sometimes we go hitech with a GPS. Sometimes we go low tech with a paper map. Sometimes we go no tech and just look out for road signs. Does not matter which we use, we sometimes get lost. And almost without fail, that is when the best adventures begin.

data.text: I have given up finding a reasonable price one with just maps. garmin edge seams to be the best option but its not cheap. I pop my phone in my back pocket find i can ride for an hour from memory when i stop and look at google maps and plan my next hour or so. works for me but mostly i ride around home. If i was regulalry touring i would get the garmin.
